article.description: Plenette Pierson scored 10 of her 17 points in the second half as Tech (No. 10 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) drew away slowly and beat stubborn Tennessee-Chattanooga 66-53 on Friday in the Paradise Classic.
article.headline: Patient Lady Raiders pull away in second half
article.linkText: Texas Tech survives UT-Chattanooga's slow-down tactics
article.story:
HONOLULU (AP) -- Texas Tech doesn't have to worry these days
about running away from the opposition.

Plenette Pierson scored 10 of her 17 points in the second half as Tech (No. 10 ESPN/USA Today, No. 10 AP) drew away slowly and beat stubborn Tennessee-Chattanooga 66-53 on Friday in the Paradise Classic.

It was the lowest output of the season for the Lady Raiders (6-1) and the second straight game in which they failed to score 70 points.

"The people we've played lately have understood it's important
to slow the tempo against us and not give us so many offensive
opportunities,'' Texas Tech coach Marsha Sharp said. "The most
important thing to do is be consistent when you get those opportunities and score.''

Tech led most for most of the first half, but Chattanooga (6-2)
went ahead 34-33 on Jennifer Wilson's turnaround just 21 seconds
before the break. Texas Tech's Miklannet Tennal made a 3-pointer
with 1 second left in the half to put Tech in front to stay.

"It gave us a little momentum going into the locker room, which
we needed, and at least let us have the lead,'' Sharp said. "I
think if you can do that going into half you usually feel a little
bit better about it.''

   Texas Tech opened the second half with a 14-2 run, including
eight points from Pierson, and maintained a double-figures lead for
the rest of the game.

   "Being the senior this year on the team I think I have to take
that leadership role when the team's down get my team motivated and
ready to go,'' Pierson said.

   Jia Perkins and Natalie Ritchie added 10 points for Texas Tech
and Cisti Greenwalt had six blocks.

   "We felt a little more urgency at the beginning of the second
half and understood that two things needed to happen: (Pierson)
needed to touch the basketball some, and that we needed to play a
little bit harder on the defensive end, get over the top of some
picks and defend the shooters a little better,'' Sharp said.

   Nneka Irons led Chattanooga with 12 points, but just two in the
second half. The Lady Mocs led Texas Tech in rebounds 40-39, the
first time the Lady Raiders have been outrebounded this season.

   Texas Tech jumped out to an 8-0 lead to start the game, led by
six points from Pierson and three blocks by Greenwalt. A 9-0
Chattanooga run capped by Wilson's jumper late in the first half
gave the Lady Mocs their only lead of the game until Tennals'
3-pointer just before halftime.

   "We may have been a little intimidated early and then when
things went our way I think we did get some confidence and felt
like we could play with them,'' said Chattanooga coach Wes Moore.
